title: Uvalde Postpones Decision to Fire School Police Chief
abstract: The South Texas school district said it would delay a decision on terminating the chief who led the schools’ response to a school shooting.

multimedia.caption: Chief Pete Arredondo, center, was supposed to lead the response, according to school protocol, but instead contributed to the chaos and misinformation among responding officers.
multimedia.copyright: Mikala Compton/USA TODAY NETWORK, via Via Reuters

multimedia.caption: Chief Pete Arredondo, center, was supposed to lead the response, according to school protocol, but instead contributed to the chaos and misinformation among responding officers.

title: California Officials Revisit Airbnb Rules Amid Pandemic Tourism Boom
abstract: San Diego, Marin County, San Bernardino County and more have approved rules this year to restrict short-term rentals.

multimedia.caption: A new short-term rental property in Joshua Tree, Calif. Two years ago, Somewhere, a property development company, bought this piece of land for $40,000. The listing is now renting for $1,031 a night.
multimedia.copyright: Cody James for The New York Times

title: Newsom Raises His Profile With Hardball Tactics, Starting With a Gun Bill
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed legislation that would provide a minimum $10,000 award to residents who successfully sue makers of illegal guns.

title: He Built a Home to Survive a Civil War. Tragedy Found Him Anyway.
abstract: C. Wesley Morgan once believed that the place he built, which included a 2,000-square-foot bunker, was the safest house in Kentucky.

title: On U.S. Foreign Policy, the New Boss Acts a Lot Like the Old One
abstract: The Biden administration has charted the same course as the Trump administration on strategic priorities like China, the Middle East and U.S. military deployments.

multimedia.caption: President Biden vowed on the campaign trail to break from paths taken by the previous administration.

title: After Recent Turmoil, the Race for Texas Governor Is Tightening
abstract: A series of tragedies and challenges have soured the mood of Texans and made the governor’s race perhaps the most competitive since the 1990s.

multimedia.caption: Gov. Greg Abbott addressed the 2022 National Rifle Association conference in a prerecorded video in Houston on May 27, three days after the Uvalde school shooting. He and his Democratic challenger, Beto O’Rourke, differ widely on gun control issues.
multimedia.copyright: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Gov. Greg Abbott addressed the 2022 National Rifle Association conference in a prerecorded video in Houston on May 27, three days after the Uvalde school shooting. He and his Democratic challenger, Beto O’Rourke, differ widely on gun control issues.

title: Heat Records Expected to Be Broken on Sunday
abstract: Temperatures were forecast to set daily record highs in New York and Boston, among other places, before the weather cools down on Tuesday, meteorologists said.

multimedia.caption: Tony Lopez at East River Park in New York on Sunday. Temperatures were expected to exceed New York’s previous July 24 record of 97 degrees, which was set in 2010, forecasters said.
multimedia.copyright: Gabby Jones for The New York Times

title: Mississippi Fires Lawyer Trying to Recoup Misused Welfare Funds
abstract: The lawyer had issued a subpoena that could reveal details about the involvement of a former governor and a football star in the scandal.
byline: By Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas

multimedia.caption: A subpoena issued to the University of Southern Mississippi Athletic Foundation involving the building of a volleyball facility asks for communications that foundation members may have had with individuals including Brett Favre.

title: U.S. Taking Emergency Steps to Protect Sequoias From Wildfires
abstract: The U.S. Forest Service will expedite plans to clear brush that fuels fires and take other measures to protect the centuries-old trees.

title: Utah University Admits ‘Shortcomings’ in Handling Domestic Abuse Case
abstract: The University of Utah acknowledged missteps in how it responded to concerns about the safety of a student, Zhifan Dong, 19, who was killed in February.

multimedia.caption: Zhifan Dong was found dead in a Salt Lake City motel room. Her ex-boyfriend has been charged with murder.
Zhifan Dong was found dead in a Salt Lake City motel room. Her ex-boyfriend has been charged with murder.
Zhifan Dong was found dead in a Salt Lake City motel room. Her ex-boyfriend has been charged with murder.

title: On the Docket: Atlanta v. Trumpworld
abstract: Eighteen months into a criminal investigation of election interference by Donald J. Trump and his allies, a Georgia prosecutor is beginning to show the broad contours of her inquiry.
byline: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim

multimedia.caption: Fani T. Willis, the Atlanta area district attorney, is bringing a case against the former president’s supporters that may involve racketeering charges.
multimedia.copyright: Nicole Craine for The New York Times

title: In Jan. 6 Hearings, Gender Divide Has Been Strong Undercurrent
abstract: An investigation that has revealed grave threats to democracy, plotted and carried out mostly by men, has a heavily female cast of narrators who have paid a public price for speaking out.
byline: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: Matthew Pottinger, left, and Sarah Matthews at the Jan. 6 hearing on Thursday. Like other female witnesses, Ms. Matthews quickly came under attack for her appearance before the House committee.
multimedia.copyright: Doug Mills/The New York Times

title: Rapidly Spreading California Wildfire Forces 3,000 Residents to Evacuate
abstract: The Oak fire, near Yosemite National Park, has more than tripled in size since Friday and threatened thousands of structures.

title: Turkey’s Leader Remains a Headache for Biden Despite Aiding in Ukraine Deal
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey assisted in brokering an agreement to unblock Ukrainian grain but has alarmed U.S. officials on other fronts.

multimedia.caption: Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, center, helped secure a deal with Russia to ease a blockade of Ukraine’s grain.

title: Meet the Canine Officers Guarding American Agriculture
abstract: With international travel returning to prepandemic levels, these floppy-eared hounds are sniffing out deadly diseases and pests at border crossings one mango or sausage at a time.

multimedia.caption: Hair-E, the fastest and one of the most industrious dogs at Dulles International Airport, intercepts 12 to 18 prohibited items a day.

title: After Parkland, One Question Remains: What Is Justice?
abstract: Four years after the Hoyers lost their youngest child in the Florida school shooting, a jury will decide whether the killer should get the death penalty. The Hoyers had to decide, too.
byline: By Audra D. S. Burch and Scott McIntyre
org_facet: Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School (Parkland, Fla)

multimedia.copyright: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times

title: Two Dead and 1 Missing After Flash Flooding in New Mexico
abstract: The floods came as heavy rainfall struck an area that had been burned by the state’s largest recorded wildfire. More rain is expected across the state next week.

title: Wes Moore Wins the Democratic Primary for Maryland Governor
abstract: Mr. Moore, a celebrity author and former nonprofit executive, will aim to take back the office for Democrats after eight years under Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican who is term-limited.

multimedia.caption: Wes Moore with his wife, Dawn, at his primary-night watch party in Baltimore on Tuesday. He had endorsements from Oprah Winfrey and several top Democrats in Maryland.

title: Baltimore Prosecutor Defeated in Democratic Primary Amid Legal Woes
abstract: Marilyn Mosby, who rose to national prominence for her handling of the death of Freddie Gray, was indicted in January on charges of perjury and financial misconduct.

title: Jan. 6 Hearings Invoke Patriotism to Urge Voters to Break With Trump
abstract: On Thursday, the Jan. 6 committee made the case that Donald J. Trump’s conduct had been a violation of his Oath of Office.

title: A Hidden New Threat to U.S. Elections
abstract: Some Republican-led counties are refusing to certify election results — a move that could throw American democracy into chaos if it becomes widespread.
byline: By Blake Hounshell and Nick Corasaniti

multimedia.caption: Election workers scanning ballots last month in Lancaster, Pa. The county and two others have refused to process certain absentee ballots, which has delayed the state’s certification of its primary results.
multimedia.copyright: Hannah Beier/Reuters

title: Like the Rest of Us, Biden Learns to Live With the Risks of the Virus
abstract: The president’s symptoms improved somewhat, a day after he tested positive for Covid-19.
byline: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

multimedia.caption: President Biden held a Presidential Medal of Freedom ceremony this month at the White House, where he embraced and kissed many of the recipients. The White House has dropped many of the extraordinary pandemic safety measures around the president.

title: 2 Killed in Helicopter Crash While Fighting Idaho Wildfire
abstract: Two experienced pilots who were decorated military veterans died after their helicopter crashed while fighting the Moose fire on Thursday, officials said.

multimedia.caption: A crash that killed two pilots in Idaho was the second such fatal crash involving helicopters responding to wildfires in less than a week, the authorities said.

title: Justice Dept. Will Investigate Environmental Racism in Houston
abstract: The inquiry, part of an administration-wide racial justice initiative, came amid claims that the city has ignored illegal dumping in Black and Latino areas.

multimedia.caption: The investigation is likely to be one of the most ambitious environmental justice reviews undertaken by the Justice Department in recent years.

title: Ethics Board Moves to Penalize Jeffrey Clark, Who Aided Trump in Election Plot
abstract: A D.C. Bar office filed a complaint against Jeffrey Clark, the former Justice Department official who worked to undo the results of the 2020 election.

title: A Republican running for governor in Michigan is playing up the Jan. 6 charges against him.
abstract: In June, Ryan Kelley became the first person running in a major state or federal election to be charged with crimes related to the attack.

multimedia.caption: Ryan Kelley spoke with voters in Lansing, Mich. Mr. Kelley was charged in June with four misdemeanors connected to the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol.

abstract: Prosecutors in April dropped a first-degree murder charge against Barry Morphew, whose wife, Suzanne Morphew, disappeared in May 2020.

title: The Jan. 6 Panel After 8 Hearings: Where Will the Evidence Lead?
abstract: The House committee has set out a comprehensive narrative of the effort to overturn the 2020 election. But it’s unclear if that will be enough to achieve its legal and political goals.
byline: By Alan Feuer and Michael S. Schmidt
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: The eighth hearing of the House committee investigating Jan. 6 focused on President Donald J. Trump’s inaction during the assault.
